_({C} represents colorless mana.)_
At the beginning of combat on your turn, reveal the top card of your library. If a creature card is revealed this way, you may have creatures you control other than Deceiver of Form become copies of that card until end of turn. You may put that card on the bottom of your library.

text:
Just throwing this out there, we ever thought about doing our own tier/tank system for Edh decks? Or a definition of casual/competitive?

Would cause an absolute shitstorm of debates and “you’re wrong”, but... would be fun
I know <@U286Q175Y> has quietly added budget filters at one point, don’t actually know if they have stuck around or whatever

I’d not rather get into the casual/competitive debate.
Competitive means different things to different people in my opinion, and I dislike the fact that the term “competitive” is being monopolized by cEDH.
If people really care, they can use the advanced filters to search for decks containing high amounts of fast mana.

There's a budget/expensive Theme Selection tool people can use. That generally gets you in that range. I dunno how quiet the release was, I wrote an article on it :wink:

As for the casual/competitive debate, I'm not sure that's a fire worth stoking. Bridging that gap seems more important than giving it greater definition
The commander cookout guys were going through that idea of tiered commanders. There is a list that some folks put way too much effort into maintaining on tappedout of all the commanders into X-tiers.

It's also such a shifting scale. I kind of inadvertently kicked the living shit out of a couple of new players last week with my Talrand deck which barely costs more than a precon and isn't even running many counterspells. It's not competitive in any sense, except that when you spend your entire turn casting a seven drop dragon and before the end of your turn I unsummon it to make a drake for 1, then Brainstorm into Quicken into See Beyond into Anticipate into Opt and start my turn with a pile of drakes and a full grip it looks competitive as hell.
Those guys could have been running Gaea's Cradles and the full suite of 0 mana rocks in those decks making them more "competitive" and it still wouldn't have mattered

Folks tend to conflate competitive and powerful. Competitive decks are, without real exception, combo decks designed to get their combo off by turn 3 or 4 at the most and win the game. Decks can certainly be powerful without being competitive. Most EDH players who level up have powerful decks that they call competitive.

I think Jason's 75% theory hits it well enough when he talks about skewing towards powerful effects or consistency in doing whatever you want to do. The real "competitive" decks are not only doing big and powerful things but doing them with high consistency.

I like making my decks with big powerful spells but I don't put much tutor/insane card filtering in them. Sure I might cast something insane now and then, but it's only 1 out of 5 games instead of literal every game like the real competitive decks. But to a "casual" player powerful=competitive, so no matter what we're always talking on different levels because we all define it differently.
There are groups that ban counterspells because they think they’re OP. There are objectively powerful decks but the abstract perception of power is tough to pin down
Yup
We just ban <@U33EGB4TX>
Why? He’s hardly overpowered
Tier 5 at best :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:
You haven’t smelled him.
A few iterations of the deck ago, my ezuri deck cast [[rewind]] into [[dismiss]] and had a kid about quit.

_"The best denials are simply that: a beginning and end unchanged, a dream with no memory."_

_"There is nothing you can do that I cannot simply deny." —Ertai, wizard adept_

text: And I'm about as OP as a slug.
Quit casting free counterspells.
Wait until they hear about Mana drain!
Mana drain should have a clause “caster plays with Mana Burn for the rest of the game.”
It still wouldn't matter 99% of the time
It would matter. Oh...it would matter. You’d forget and burn yourself.
Just traded for one of those for Kruphix, I’m excited to have it draw a lot of hate from my buddies
If you play Kruphix I don’t think you get to call them buddies for long.
It was my second ever deck, if they hate it they sure suppress that feeling admirably
They’re nicer than you.
Woof
I won’t be surprised if the first time I see Mana Drain someone rips it from my library with a Mind’s Dilation
Someone nevermore's you naming mana drain.
My Gonti deck loves seeing mana drain.
My first ever game with a Mana Drain and Gonti took it
Gonti gonna getcha.
Gonti gone got
I bet it did work that game, so you got to see it played! Achievement unlocked!
I have a guy in my Meta who hates playing against my Gonti deck because each time I wind up stealing all of his combo pieces.
Darn. Combo player can't combo.
You still need the cards to combo.
If you're playing a combo deck you have to expect people to not just let you combo them out.
Those who live in cannons made of glass...
They have counters and such for that...unless Gonti has those too.
#GontiGonnaGetcha
I have yet to achieve a turn1 Gonti but I’ll get there one day. Dark Ritual into either sol ring or mana Crypt.

[[Oathsworn Vampire]] is a 3rd gravecrawler, etc. Since it's triggered by lifegain on a turn, you're free to sack this bad boy as often as you like with Ashnod's Altar and generate infinite colorless mana if [[Pitiless Plunderer]] is out.

Creature — Vampire Knight
Oathsworn Vampire enters the battlefield tapped.
You may cast Oathsworn Vampire from your graveyard if you gained life this turn.
_"My conquistadors are never slain, merely laid to rest." —Queen Miralda the Pious_
*2/2*
